facts.text: Bhaichand Amolukh Vora, father of Chhotalal Bhaichand, started a firm in 1910 to work as principal agents for a number of insurance companies.

anchor.surface_text: One Bhaichand Amolukh Vora, father of Chhotalal Bhaichand, started a firm in 1910, to work as principal agents for a number of insurance companypanies.

facts.text: Partners in the firm were Bhaichand Vora, Chhotalal Bhaichand, and Nathubhai Patel.

anchor.surface_text: In that firm, in addition to Bhaichand Vora and Chhotalal Bhaichand, one Nathubhai Patel was also a partner.

facts.text: Bhaichand Vora died in 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Bhaichand Vora died in 1948, and the two surviving partners companytinued as the firm.

facts.text: Nathubhai Patel died in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Nathubhai Patel died in 1949, and it is stated that the firm thereafter companysisted of Chhotalal Bhaichand and his wife, Bai Lalitaben.

facts.text: After 1949, the firm consisted of Chhotalal Bhaichand and his wife Bai Lalitaben.

anchor.surface_text: Nathubhai Patel died in 1949, and it is stated that the firm thereafter companysisted of Chhotalal Bhaichand and his wife, Bai Lalitaben.

facts.text: Insurance Amendment Act, 1950 (No. 67 of 1950) came into force in June 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In June 1950, the Insurance  Amendment  Act, 1950  No. 67 of 1950 , came into force, which amended the Insurance Act 1938  No. 4 of 1938 ,

facts.text: The Act prohibited insurers from appointing principal agents after seven years from commencement of Act No. 67 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: by adding a new section  42B  by which the insurers were prohibited after the expiration of seven years from the companymencement of Act No. 67 of 1950, from appointing, or transacting any insurance business in India through a principal agent.

facts.text: Chhotalal Bhaichand accepted a job as assistant manager of the New India Assurance company.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the firm is that Chhotalal Bhaichand, realising that the business of principal agents was to companye to an end after the expiry of sever years, looked for other sources of employment and accepted a job as assistant manager of the New India Assurance companypany.

facts.text: Chhotalal Bhaichand withdrew from the firm.

anchor.surface_text: He withdrew from the firm, and the old firm was reconstituted from January 1, 1953, though the deed of partnership was executed on April 22, 1953.

facts.text: Old firm reconstituted from January 1, 1953; deed executed on April 22, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: He withdrew from the firm, and the old firm was reconstituted from January 1, 1953, though the deed of partnership was executed on April 22, 1953.

facts.text: New partnership consisted of Bai Manibai (5 annas), Mr. Khambatta (3 annas), Mr. Premchand D. Parikh (3 annas), minors Jayant and Harshad (1.5 annas each), balance 2 annas for reserve fund of Rs. 10,000.

anchor.surface_text: By this deed, the partnership companysisted of three persons with shares as follows Bai Manibai  mother of Chhotalal Bhaichand  - 5 annas in the rupee. Mr. Khambatta - 3 annas in the rupee. Mr. Premchand D. Parikh - 3 annas in the rupee. Two minor sons of Chhotalal Bhaichand, Jayant and Harshad, were also admitted to the benefits of the partnership to the extent of 1 1/2 annas in the rupee, each. The balance of 2 annas in the rupee was earmarked to build up a reserve fund of Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: Application for registration of new firm under section 26A for assessment year 1954-55 (calendar year 1953).

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1954-55, companyresponding to the year of account, calendar year 1953, an application for the registration of this new firm was made under section 26A of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer declined registration by order dated September 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer by his order dated September 30, 1954, declined registration, holding that the firm belonged solely to Chhotalal Bhaichand

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner ordered registration of the firm on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation of Manibai that she received Rs. 5,000 out of that amount and spent it on charities was number accepted. On appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, registration of the firm was ordered.

facts.text: Tribunal set aside AAC order, found Manibai and two minor sons not real partners, partnership consisted of Chhotalal Bhaichand and two others, but restored ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal to the Tribunal, the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was, in its turn, set aside, and the Tribunal reached the companyclusion that Manibai and the two minor sons were number the real partners of the new firm, but that the partnership companysisted of Chhotalal Bhaichand and two others. The Tribunal, in spite of this finding, restored the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Firm applied to Tribunal for reference on questions arising from its order, suggested 18 questions; Tribunal declined.

anchor.surface_text: The firm then applied for a reference of the questions arising from the Tribunals order, and suggested as many as 18 questions. The Tribunal declined the reference by an order,

facts.text: Firm applied to High Court of Bombay under section 66(2), High Court declined first question, directed reference on recast second question.

holdings.text: There was material on record to support the Tribunal's finding that the firm which asked for registration was not a real firm.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the first ground, it is quite obvious that there was material on which the finding could be based. ... Without any such action, the decision of the Tribunal, that the firm which asked for registration was not a real firm, cannot be said to be founded on no material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court lists specific evidentiary gaps (Lalitabai's disappearance without mention, no adjustment entries, no insurer communications or appointments, unchanged bank accounts/PoA) as material supporting Tribunal's conclusion of sham partnership.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's order is not founded on no material and the High Court did not err in declining to call for a reference on whether the finding lacked material support.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the first ground, it is quite obvious that there was material on which the finding could be based. If Chhotalal withdrew from the business... cannot be said to be founded on no material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit material identified justifies upholding Tribunal's factual finding on partnership genuineness; no question of law arises for reference.

holdings.text: Tribunal orders must be read as a whole to assess if material facts considered fairly, evidence weighed, and conclusion uncoloured by irrelevance or prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: We must read the order of the Tribunal as a whole to determine whether every material fact, for and against the assessee, has been considered fairly and with due care whether the evidence pro and con has been considered in reaching the final conclusion...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedent from Homi Jehangir Gheesta v. CIT, court adopts holistic review standard rather than microscopic sentence-by-sentence scrutiny.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's order is not vitiated by defects such as failure to consider material fairly, ignoring pro/con evidence, or prejudice/irrelevant considerations.
holdings.reasoning_summary: After full examination, no such vitiation found; distinguishes Dhirajlal and Omar Salay as not requiring sentence-level microscopy.

holdings.text: In considering probabilities from proved facts, Tribunal does not indulge in conjectures, surmises or suspicions; any motive speculation here did not materially affect the finding based on solid facts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Motive remarks obiter; core finding rests on undisputed evidentiary lacks, not speculation.

holdings.text: This case falls within the ruling in Homi Jehangir Gheesta v. Commissioner of Income-tax.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of Gheesta standards upholds Tribunal; appeal against HC refusal implicitly dismissed.

precedents.cited_holding: We must read the order of the Tribunal as a whole to determine whether every material fact, for and against the assessee, has been considered fairly and with due care whether the evidence pro and con has been considered in reaching the final conclusion and whether the conclusion reached by the Tribunal has been coloured by irrelevant consideration or matters of prejudice.
